\subsection{ hypothesis for a methods paper}

I dug up the second edition of the book by Lindsay from 2020.
He has one paragraph on page 30 about methods papers in his discussion of hypotheses.
He lays out several scenarios.
First, it is possible to have a hypothesis about methodology because the development of methodology is driven by the belief that method A will be better than method B.
Second, the development of the new method will enable me to do something that was impossible to study satisfactory before before.
Third, this new method is just as precise as an old method, but it is less expensive.
Obviously, the hypothesis that gets stated has to be tested.
This testing can require additional work beyond what was initially sufficient for a report.
Nonetheless, the hypothesis will lead to a better organized and more coherent paper that would attract more attention and have a higher impact.



\subsection{ retro hypothesis}

You may have to write a paper about a set of data for which hypothesis was established at the time of data collection or the record of that hypothesis was lost.
In this situation, it's still possible to proceed with a hypothesis.
I have pondered many times about the difficulty posed by this situation. 
Lindsay has provided a solution in just a few words.
You would open that second paragraph with a statement like 'these data presented a unique opportunity for us to test the hypothesis that ....' .
That is, you propose a hypothesis that was developed after the paper was written.
